Award.AwardTitle: Colorado State University-Pueblo Robert Noyce Scholars Program: Meeting the K-12 Mathematics Educational Needs of Southeastern Colorado

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Colorado State University-Pueblo (CSU-Pueblo) is strengthening 7-12 mathematics achievement throughout the region of southeastern Colorado by providing incentives and support to attract 19 junior and senior mathematics majors and 9 STEM professionals to the teaching profession. A long-standing and highly effective collaboration among faculty in the Departments of Mathematics/Physics and Teacher Education at CSU-Pueblo, faculty at 4 area community colleges, 2 local school districts, and 5 community partners is providing the Noyce Scholars and STEM professionals with the strong content and pedagogical training required to teach in high needs schools, and to be retained in the teaching profession beyond their obligatory service period.

CSU-Pueblo, the only federally designated Hispanic serving university in Colorado, is providing the majority of teachers to its service area. Many school districts and communities within this service area are facing substantial challenges, including low levels of family income and education, historically poor achievement, and graduation rates that lag behind those in other parts of the state. The enhanced mathematics education in the 7-12 classrooms in this service area is providing underserved students the opportunity to have academic success and to find a rewarding career in a STEM area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Colorado State University-Pueblo (CSU-Pueblo) Noyce Scholars Program was established with the goal of strengthening 7-12 mathematics achievement in southeastern Colorado. The only federally designated Hispanic-serving university in Colorado, CSU-Pueblo serves the southeastern quadrant of the state, providing the majority of teachers to its service area. Many communities within this service area face substantial challenges, including low levels of family income and education, historically poor achievement, and graduation rates that lag behind those in other parts of the state. The preparation of sufficient numbers of new teachers in mathematics, particularly teachers who are strong in their content areas, has been an especially chronic need within the region.

The major focus of this six year project (2011-2017) has thus been to provide opportunities and resources to increase the number of middle and high school mathematics teachers who are well prepared in their discipline and who successfully teach in high needs schools. Towards this end, the program has:

  • Increased opportunities for promising prospective teachers to complete their mathematics education by providing financial assistance in the form of a “forgivable loan” that requires 2 years teaching in a high-needs school for every year of financial support. In all, 23 undergraduates and 4 STEM professionals have received such support. Although 4 loan recipients are in repayment, 20 individuals have completed their licensure program – a 25% increase compared to the previous 5-year period. Currrently, 18 of our program completers are teaching in high-needs school districts (including 4 who have fulfilled their service obligation), and 1 is seeking a teaching position. With an additional 4 scholars are on track to begin teaching by December 2018, financial resources provided by the program has thus allowed 23 individuals who are now or soon will be teaching in high needs settings to complete mathematics course work they would not have otherwise afforded, and helped to retain them in the teacher education program.
  • Expanded support to new teachers during the initial years of teaching by providing mentoring to 20 student teachers through a new collaborative model of supervision, and to 16 early career teachers during their first two years of teaching through a new model of induction support. Additional induction support provided to our early career teachers included regular seminars focused on case study work that provided graduates opportunities to critically reflect on their teaching and assessment practices as they researched and implemented new ideas in their classrooms.
  • Strengthened the pool of future mathematics teachers by providing 32 freshman and sophomore students from CSU-Pueblo and its community college partners with paid summer internships. Of these, 27 interns participated in an intensive "Explore Teaching" program built around a Noyce Summer Math Academy for students entering grades 7-10, with interns and mentors collaborating closely as co-teachers to plan, deliver and assess every aspect of Academy instruction. This program further offered leadership opportunities to 7 scholars through its "Junior Mentor" and “Senior-mentor-in-training” components, and provided nearly 400 students from two high-needs K-12 partner districts with a no-cost summer mathematics experience. To date, 9 of our 32 interns are teaching in high needs settings.
  • Enhanced the ability of regional mathematics teachers to meet the educational needs of a diverse student population by offering high quality professional development and networking opportunities. In addition to numerous teaching conference opportunities provided to our scholars, the program allowed over 100 local teachers to complete workshops with nationally recognized mathematics educators at its bi-annual Noyce Mathematics Education Seminar series.
  • Strengthened the reflective and leadership skills of 23 novice teachers through early and regular participation in professional conferences, workshops and a unique mentorship model. Additionally, 4 early career teachers participated in a special Noyce Leadership Program that helped to transform them into more developed leaders than would otherwise have been possible. Many of our graduates have already assumed leadership roles in their schools and districts, and several have presented or led workshops at regional conferences.
  • Strengthened the capacity of the regional mathematics education community to prepare and support new teachers, with 7 university and K-12 mathematics educators gaining experience as mentors to student teachers, early career teachers and summer interns.

Because our Scholars are enthusiastic with strong preparation in both content and pedagogy, they are well positioned to have an immediate positive impact on the students whom they teach, and the schools and districts in which they work. In addition to the long term effects of program graduates on the mathematics achievement of 7-12 students, the project's evaluation component has addressed questions related to recruitment and retention of pre-service and novice mathematics teachers and the impact of strong teacher content knowledge in mathematics on student levels of achievement which will contribute to the current understanding of teacher education and its relation to 7-12 student achievement.
